```javascript

var arr = F.sitemap('sitemap-identificator');

for (var i = 0, length = arr.length; i < length; i++) {
    value.sitemap   // current sitemap id
    value.id        // current item id
    value.name      // current item name
    value.url       // current item url
    value.last      // is the last item?
    value.first     // is the first item?
    value.index     // current item index in sitemap (in the parent tree)

}

api.body:
`FrameworkConfiguration` contains framework settings. Settings can be stored in these files:

```html
/app/config
/app/config-
/app/config-release
/app/config-rest
```

The `config` file is loaded for all framework modes (`release`, ``, `test`) and other configs are loaded according to the framework mode. The configuration file is a plain text file.

__Example__:

```html
name                         : My Web Site name
version                      : 1.01
author                       : Peter Sirka
secret                       : mySECRET1.01
default-image-quality        : 96
...
...
...
```

## Auto-Converting values with sub-type

The framework converts/binds values according the sub-type. So you can read converted values in the application:

```html
my-custom-object-raw      (Object)    : { name: 'Total.js', date: new Date() }
my-custom-object-json     (JSON)      : { "name": "Total.js" }
my-custom-number          (number)    : 320.34
my-custom-boolean         (boolean)   : true
my-custom-date            (date)      : 2016-07-26
my-custom-array           (array)     : [1, 2, 3, 4]
binds-environment-value   (env)       : process.env
```

- [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools)

## Custom options for dependencies

`+v2.4.0` supports custom options for all dependencies.

```html
// type#name       (Object)  : { name: 'value', number: 30, boolean: false }
// a real example:
module#monitor     (Object)  : { url: '/mymonitor/'}
```

> __Total.js__ project has a _simple directory structure_. __All directories are optional__ and you can rewrite each path of directory in the framework configuration file.

## Directories

```html
/configs
/controllers
/databases
/definitions
/isomorphic
/logs
/models
/modules
/packages
/private
/public
/resources
/source
/startup
/tests
/tmp
/views
/workers
```

### Directory: configs

`+v1.9.x` - Directory contains only specific config files. Files are loaded in the order and before are read base config files. The framework recognizes files with `-`, `-release` and `-test` or without (for all modes) name. Config files have same structure as base config files.

```html
/configs/my-custom-config         - this config file is loaded for all modes (, release, test)
/configs/my-custom-config-   - this config file is loaded only for  mode
/configs/my-custom-config-release - this config file is loaded only for release mode
/configs/my-custom-config-test    - this config file is loaded only for test mode
```

### Directory: controllers

Directory contains only controllers. In controller you can define routes with different actions. Controllers are __most important__ feature in the framework.

- [How do controllers work?](#pages~Controllers)

---

### Directory: databases

Directory contains __NoSQL embedded databases__ (if are). NoSQL database is a plain text file with serialized documents in JSON format. Some [3rd modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules) store a small data in this directory.

- [How does NoSQL database work?](#pages~NoSQL)
- [Example: Database](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/contact-form)

---

### Directory: definitions

Directory contains all definitions. The definition defines behaviour of the framework. The definition is great for change a behaviour of e.g. modules.

- [How do definitions work?](#pages~Definitions)

---

### Directory: isomorphic

`+v1.9.x` - Directory contains an isomorphic code. The isomorphic means: one code for server-side and client-side.

- [How does isomorphic work?](#pages~Isomorphic)

---

### Directory: logs

Directory contains logs. Log file is plain text file. You can append a log message via `framework.log(message)` everywhere. Log filename is created by date.

- [Example: Logs](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/logs)

---

### Directory: models

Directory contains models. The model can contain functions or some [schemas](#api~SchemaBuilder). Recommended for database models.

- [How do models work?](#pages~Models)
- [Example: Models](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/models)

---

### Directory: modules

Directory contains extended modules. The module can create routes or can contain classes, functions or constants. You can download existing modules or you can create your own module.

- [How do modules work?](#pages~Modules)
- [Example: Modules](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-modules)
- [Download 3rd modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules)

---

### Directory: private

`+v1.9.x` - This directory is private directory for storing custom data.

---

### Directory: public

This directory is published directory and contains all static files (JavaScripts, CSS files, Pictures, Fonts, Documents, Videos, Uploads, etc.). Browser can get (almost) everything from the public directory.

---

### Directory: resources

If you create web pages that will be read by speakers of different languages, you must provide a way for readers to view the page in their own language. Resources are solution. The resource file has same syntax as a config file.

- [How do resources work?](#pages~Resources)
- [Example: Resources](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/localization-resources)

---

### Directory: startup

__NEW__ `+v2.x.x` - A startup directory can contain scripts which they are executed only onetime. All executed scripts are renamed automatically and on the second start they are not executed. Scripts are executed as worker outside application scope.

---
### Directory: source

This directory contains a business logic of your application. The source file can contain functions or objects which can be exported and used in each part of application.

- [Example: Source](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-business-logic-source)

---

### Directory: packages

This directory contains packages. The package is a file which contains more files packed in one package file. The package behaves like a module (is same as module).

- [How do packages work?](#pages~Packages)

---

### Directory: tests

Test directory contains scripts for assertion testing. In assertion test you can test e.g. controller routing.

- [Example: Tests](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/assertion-testing)

---

### Directory: tmp

This directory is a temporary directory and contains temporary files. The framework stores some compiled files, internal cache and form uploads into this directory.

---

### Directory: views

This directory contains views and layouts.

---

### Directory: workers

This directory contains workers. The worker creates a new independent thread, which it can communicate with framework through events.

- [Example: Workers](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/workers)
- [Example: Generating sitemap with the Worker](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/xml-sitemap-workers)

require('total.js');

> __The Package__ is same as Total.js module, but the Package can contain multiple files packed in the single `package` file. ```plain Initialization: Modules --> Packages --> Models --> Themes --> Definitions --> Controllers ``` __More informations__ - the package is a plain text file with `.package` extension - the framework unpacks the package into the temporary directory - all packages are stored in `your-app/packages/` directory - `index.js` is the main file of the package and has to __the same structure as the module__ - `exports.install` is executed automatically and once - views can be mapped from the package easily: `controller.view('@packagename/myview')` - views and static files have to be mapped manually via `F.map()` - you can create unlimited count of packages - the package can be injected from an URL address - [Download packages](https://github.com/totaljs/modules) `PACKAGE == MODULE with dependencies` --- ## How to create the package? You can create Total.js package easily. First is need to install the framework from NPM as __global__ modul. Then you have to use in a terminal: `$ totalpackage --help`. ### Create an own package First we have to create a module: __Open terminal:__ ```bash mkdir hello-world-package-directory cd hello-world-package ``` __1. Create__ `hello-world-package-directory/index.js`: ```javascript exports.install = function(options) { console.log('Hello from the package!'); // Routing: F.route('/hello-world/', view_greeting); // A static file mapping: F.map('/myview.js', '@helloworld/myview.js'); }; function view_greeting() { // IMPORTANT: for the view will be used a layout out of this package. // or create your own this.layout('@helloworld/layout') this.view('@helloworld/myview'); } ``` __2. Create__ `hello-world-package-directory/myview.html`: ```html
Hello from the package
``` __3. Create__ `hello-world-package-directory/myview.js`: ```javascript alert('Hello world!'); ``` __3. Open terminal:__ ```bash $ cd hello-world-package-directory $ totalpackage create helloworld.package ``` Total.js creates the file `my-package.package` in the current directory. Copy this file into the `my-total-js-app/packages` and run the framework. The framework unpacks the content of the package into the temporary directory and then it executes `index.js` as main file. Open: `http://127.0.0.1:8000/hello-world/` in your browser. ## Booting Booting is a special feature in Total.js framework. The file `index.js` in a package can contain: ### Boot all files The framework unpacks package and evaluates all files according to the framewok's directory structure. So the framework loads controllers, modules, definitions, configs, etc. from the package. ```javascript exports.booting = true; ``` ### Boot as application The framework unpacks package and it runs it as an application. Example: `F.http('', { package: 'myapp.package' })`. ```javascript exports.booting = 'root'; ``` ### Custom options via configuration files `+v2.4.0` supports a new feature: the custom options for modules which they can be defined in configuration files. Each package is a module in the end. ```html // type#name (Object) : { name: 'value', number: 20, boolean: true } module#monitor (Object) : { url: '/mymonitor/' } module#webcounter (Object) : { xhr: true, ip: true } ``` __Usage in own modules:__ ```javascript exports.install = function(options) { // options === CUSTOM OPTIONS }; ```

pages.body: The resource file is the simple KEY/VALUE dictionary and you can store into it everything. Resources are simple and effective. On the resources is builded [localization](#pages~Localization). - The resource is the plain text file with `.resource` extension. - Framework loads each resource when is needed. - You can create unlimited count of resources. - Resources are readonly. - Resources are used for validation. [Example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation) - [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools) ## Examples - [Example: Localization](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/localization-resources) - [Example: Validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation) - [Example: Custom validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation-custom) --- ## The definition ### resources/default.resource ```html key1 : value1 // comment key2 : value2 key3 : with the tag ``` ### resources/en.resource ```html key1 : value1-en // comment key2 : value2-en key3 : with the tag-en ``` ### resources/de.resource ```html key1 : value1-de // comment key2 : value2-de key3 : with the tag-de ``` ## Reading values from resources - [Documentation: RESOURCE()](#api~global~RESOURCE) - [Documentation: framework.resource()](#api~Framework~framework.resource) - [Documentation: controller.resource()](#api~FrameworkController~controller.resource) ```javascript console.log(RESOURCE('key1')); console.log(framework.resource('key1')); // value1 console.log(RESOURCE('en', 'key1')); // value1-en console.log(RESOURCE('de', 'key1')); // value1-de ``` ### View engine ```html @{resource('key3')} @{!resource('key3')} @{resource('en', 'key3')} @{!resource('en', 'key3')} @{resource('de', 'key3')} @{!resource('de', 'key3')} ```

pages.body:
`Views` can render HTML. You can render "view" in "view" and "view" is rendered into the layout at the end. The view engine supports conditions, loops, sections, helpers and inline helpers. --- __More informations__ - View is the plain HTML file with `.html` extension. - __IMPORTANT:__ Server tags are represented as `@{keyword}` (encoded) tag and `@{!keyword}` (raw) tag. - Views are synchronous. - Views are compiled into the function. - All views (HTML) are minimized under the compilation (total.js saves memory). - The layout is rendered at the last (if it's not disabled). - You can render some view into the string. - The default layout filename is `layout.html`, in older versions has been `_layout.html`. - When the path starts with `~` char then the framework maps the path into the views root directory - When the path starts with `.` char then the framework skips `.` and it loads the view without support of the framework configuration (the view can be outside of app directory) - [View properties and methods](#api~FrameworkViews) - [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools) --- ### Examples Most [examples](https://github.com/totaljs/examples) contain views. - [Example: Views](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views) - [Example: Views with XHR](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-xhr) - [Example: Views places and sections](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-place-sections) - [Example: Views meta](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-meta) - [Example: Views inline JavaScript compress](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-javascript-compress) - [Example: Views head](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-head) - [Example: Views custom helper](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-custom-helper) --- ## Repository vs. Model Exist many ways how to send some values between controllers and views. You can transfer data between the controller and the view via `controller.repository` or `controller.view('name', model)`. ```javascript exports.install = function() { F.route('/', view_homepage); }; function view_homepage() { var self = this; self.repository.firstname = 'Peter'; self.view('my-view', { firstname: 'Lucia' }); } ``` A picture describes the behaviour of variables: ![Repository vs. model](resources/viewengine-repository-vs-model.png) ```html

My View

Get the value from the repository: @{repository.firstname}
Get the value from the model: @{model.firstname}
@{view('partial-view-1', model)}
@{view('partial-view-2')}
``` ## Defining the layout You can create unlimited layouts and customize them according to the name. The layout is same as the view but only one different is tag `@{body}`. Into this tag is rendered the view. ### The layout example ```html @{meta} @{head} @{import('default.css', 'default.js', 'favicon.ico')}
@{section('panel')} @{body}
@{view('footer')} ``` Read more about [view engine tags](#api~FrameworkViews). --- ## Defining the view You can create unlimited views. ### Example ```html @{meta('Title', 'Description (optional)', 'Keywords (optional)')}
Hello World!
@{view('products', [{ name: 'A', price: 23.32 }, { name: 'B', price: 32.10 }])} @{view('users', model)} @{view('products', [{ name: 'A', price: 23.32 }, { name: 'B', price: 32.10 }, { name: 'C', price: 15.22 }])} ``` ## Escaping The view engine automatically escape HTML entities. Tag with `@{!` renders the raw value. ```html @{repository.tag = 'Hello World'}
ESCAPED: @{repository.tag}
RAW: @{!repository.tag}
``` __Output__: ```html
ESCAPED: Hello <b>World</b>
RAW: Hello World
``` ## Conditions - supports `else if` in `+v1.9.1` ```html @{if user === null}
sign in
@{else}
sign up
@{fi}

@{if model.name === 'Peter'} @{if model.name === 'Lucia'}
Here is Lucia.
@{else}
Here is Peter.
@{fi} @{fi}

@{if model.name !== 'Peter'}
Here is @{model.name}
@{fi} ``` ## Looping __Array looping__: ```html @{foreach m in [1, 2, 3, 4]}
@{m}, index: @{index}
@{end}

@{foreach property in model}
@{index}
@{property.name}
@{property.age.format('### ###')}
@{end} ``` __Object looping__: ```html @{foreach m in { name: 'Peter', age: 32 }}
property: @{m.key}, value: @{m.value}
@{end}

@{foreach property in model}
@{index}
@{property.key}
@{property.value}
@{end} ``` ## Sections __View__: ```html @{section footer}
THIS IS FOOTER FROM THE VIEW
@{end}

Homepage


``` __Layout__: ```html .... .... @{body} .... .... @{section('footer')} .... .... ``` __Output__: ```html .... ....

Homepage


.... ....
THIS IS FOOTER FROM THE VIEW
.... .... ``` ## Assignment values __SUPPORTS ONLY:__ repository, model, user, session, global, get, post and config. ```html @{repository.name = 'Peter'}

@{repository.name}

``` __Output__: ```html

Peter

``` ## Defining helpers ```javascript framework.helpers.custom = function(str, num) { // this === controller return str + ' = ' + num; }; framework.helpers.isTrue = function(value) { return value ? true : false; }; ``` ```html @{custom('Peter', 25)} @{helpers.custom('Peter', 25)} @{if helpers.isTrue(true)} Helpers in condition. The helper isTrue won't work without helpers keyword. @{fi} ``` ## Defining inline helpers The inline helper must by defined in the view. ```html @{helper address(street, city)

Address

@{street}
@{city}

@{end}
Address 1
@{address('Baker street 3', 'Wien')}
Address 2
@{address('Galvaniho 3', 'Bratislava')} ``` ## Defining custom 3rd compilers The view engine supports custom 3rd compilers. [How to write a connection to 3rd compiler?](#api~Framework~framework.onCompileView) ```html

HANDLEBARS

@{compile handlebars}

Handlebars: {{ title }}

{{ body }}

@{end}

JADE

@{compile jade} h3 View engine p Total.js is amazing! @{end} ``` ## Date feature `date` function compares the current date with date in the argument. ```html @{if date('>', '2015-01-01') && date('<', '2015-01-10 12:00')}
! Happy new year !
@{fi} @{viewToggle(date('=', '2014-08-08'), 'important-partial-view')} ``` ## Defining views in sub-directories The default controller `default.js` includes views from the default views directory `/views`. To modify this behaviour, rename the controller's filename (e.g: `controllers/site.js`) to match a directory of the same name under views (e.g: `views/site/`). The views contained within the `site` directory would be displayed. __IMPORTANT__: char `~` is very important for mapping path of views, because `~index` is still routed into the `/views/index.html`. --- ## Localization The framework automatically translates `@(text)` when compiling the views. - [How does localization work?](#pages~Localization) ```html @{meta('@(My custom title)', '@(Description to translate)')}

@(Hello world)

@(Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur ...)

@(#T-3403403030)

@(#T34930203922)

``` ## Auto binding values ```javascript function view_contactform() { this.view('contactform', { Email: '@', Name: 'Anoym' }); }; ``` ## Simple routing to static files ```html @{import('ui.js')} @{import('ui.css')} ``` __View__: ```html Email: @{text('Email')} Name: @{text('Name')} ``` __Output__: ```html Email: Name: ```

pages.body:
The localization is big tool for multilingual websites. - The framework translates views at time of compilation. - Each translated view is stored into the memory. - For generating translations is needed `total` (An executable file). - The text for translate is wrapped with `@()` tag (it will be a default text). - [Documentation: F.translate()](#api~Framework~framework.translate) - For setting the language for the current request use [F.onLocale()](#api~Framework~framework.onLocale) delegate __IMPORTANT__: - The localized text doesn't start with `#sometext` because for the framework is `sometext` key and the framework reads this key directly from the resource file. --- ## Full example ### First step You must install `total.js` as global module from NPM: ```bash $ sudo npm install -g total.js ``` ### Implementation The definition: ```javascript F.onLocale = function(req) { if (req.query.language === 'sk') return 'sk'; return 'en'; }; ``` The controller: ```javascript exports.install = function() { F.route('/', view_index); }; function view_index() { var self = this; // you can change language manually here, e.g.: // self.language = 'sk'; self.view('index'); } ``` The view: ```html @{meta('@(Title)')}

@(Hello world!)

@(total.js is web application framework for node.js)

@(#message) or @(#T80818744) is same as @(Title) (read below)
``` ### Create resource __1.__ Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ totaljs --translate ``` The Total Application finds all texts for translation and creates the resource file `translate.resource` for translation. The keys are numbers in the resource file because the framework saves the performance and memory (saves RAM). Rename below file to `en.resource`: ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Title T-52966915 : Hello world! T-1870230665 : total.js is web application framework for node.js // IMPORTANT: This line was created manually message : Direct reading ``` __2.__ I copy the content from `translate.resource` to the new resource: `/resources/sk.resource` and I translate it, e.g.: ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Titulok T-52966915 : Ahoj svet! T-1870230665 : total.js je webový framework pre node.js // IMPORTANT: This line was created manually message : Priame čítanie ``` ### Run `http://127.0.0.1:8000` ```html ... ... Title ... ...

Hello world!

total.js is web application framework for node.js

Direct reading or Title is same as Title (read below)
... ... ``` `http://127.0.0.1:8000/?language=sk` ```html ... ... Titulok ... ...

Ahoj svet!

total.js je webový framework pre node.js

Priame čítanie or Titulok is same as Titulok (read below)
... ... ``` ## Did you know? ### Resource file can contain view engine tags Resource with the localization can contain view engine markup and the markup will be evaluated. ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Hello @{user.name}! ``` ## Translation tools If you installed __total.js__ from NPM as global module then you have available translation tools. ### Tracking of new changes The command `-diff` creates the resource file with changes between two resources (newest texts and removed texts). Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ totaljs -diff en.resource de.resource ``` ### Translating text files Content of __my-translation.txt__: ```html Hello World! I help you My name is Peter. Total.js is the web application framework ``` Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ totaljs --translate my-translation.txt ``` ### Translating custom phrases Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ totaljs --translate "Hello World" ``` Output: ``` T-862545276 : Hello World ``` ### Translating views into the CSV - `+v1.9.0` ```bash $ totaljs --translatecsv ```

## Minify 3rd static files like CSS or JavaScript

Always __use CDN__. Otherwise minify unnecessary scripts or styles (e.g. from 3rd party companies) and rename to `somename.min.js` or `somename.min.css`. Framework doesn't compile minified files again and you can save the memory and CPU.

---

## Less is more in View Engine

Less of server-side code `@{}` in view engine is better for the performance. Server-side code use when you really need.

---

## Know the framework

Look into the documentation and use all framework features which you need. You don't need more except of database module or specific modules for the project.

---

## Use schemas

Schemas are great for the clean up project. With schemas you can do everything. So insert each business logic into the schemas and write unit-tests. A complete models you can share between projects.

__Themes__ (`+v1.9.4`) are very helpful for multiple designs. - independent on controllers - themes are composed from views and static files - themes can contain own static files (the framework maps them automatically) - themes support an initialization script `themes/THEME_NAME/index.js` - [__THEMES EXAMPLE__](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/themes) --- ## Initialization file ```plain Initialization: Modules --> Packages --> Models --> Themes --> Definitions --> Controllers ``` - is optional - filename `themes/THEME_NAME/index.js` ```javascript exports.install = function() { // ... // ... // space for your code // ... // ... }; ``` ## A default theme for all controllers __Configuration file__ (e.g. `config`, `config-`, `config-release` or `config-test`): ```html default-theme : THEME_NAME ``` or ```javascript F.config['default-theme'] = 'THEME_NAME'; ``` ## Change the theme in the controller ```javascript function some_action_in_controller() { var self = this; self.theme('THEME_NAME'); self.view('index'); } ``` __IMPORTANT__: - all views will be routed into the `/theme/THEME_NAME/views/` directory (with `layout`) - themes doesn't support fallback for views - behaviour is same as in views outside of themes --- ## Views ```html
CURRENT THEME: @{theme}
--- @{import('~common.css', 'default.css')} --- is same as: or @{image('logo.png')} ``` ## Public directory in themes __Directory structure__: ```html /themes/THEME_NAME/public/img/logo.png /themes/THEME_NAME/public/js/default.js /themes/THEME_NAME/public/css/default.css ``` __Listening on__: ```html http://127.0.0.1:8000/THEME_NAME/img/logo.png http://127.0.0.1:8000/THEME_NAME/js/default.js http://127.0.0.1:8000/THEME_NAME/css/default.css ``` ## Merging & Mapping - the framework identifies `=THEME_NAME` as a full theme path ```javascript // Merging F.merge('/merged-script.js', 'default.js', '=THEME_NAME/public/js/default.js'); F.merge('/merged-style.css', 'default.css', '=THEME_NAME/public/css/default.css'); // Mapping F.map('/mapped-script.js', '=THEME_NAME/public/js/default.js'); F.map('/mapped-style.css', '=THEME_NAME/public/css/default.css'); ``` ## Special cases - `~view_name` will be routed into the root of current theme `/theme/THEME_NAME/views/` - `~~view_name` will be routed into the root of `views` directory `/views/` ## Routing with themes - `F.view()` - `F.route(url, viewname)` - `F.mail()` - `controller.mail()` ```html =THEME_NAME/name : is routed into the file: /themes/THEME_NAME/views/name.html =?/name : is routed into the default theme's directory /themes/???_FRAMEWORK_DETERMINES_???/views/name.html ``` Same way are with static files but the framework recognizes extensions and by them creates routing.

A sitemap file `/sitemap` (`+v1.9.1`) is very helpful generating breadcrumb (navigation) or sitemap. The sitemap file `/sitemap` is a plain text and has same syntax as framework config file. - [Example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/sitemap) ```html /controllers /.js /release.js /sitemap ``` ## Declaration ```html ID : Name --> URL --> [Parent (OPTIONAL)] ``` ## How does it work? File: `/sitemap` e.g.: ```html homepage : Homepage --> / contact : Contact --> /contact/ --> homepage terms : Terms and Conditions --> /terms/ --> homepage privacy : @(Localized Privacy) --> @(/privacy/) --> terms ``` - sitemap `name` can be as view title (when is the title not defined in the view) - supports localization `@(Text to translate)` - `v2.0.2` URL addreses can be localized too ### Usage in views __View layout.html__: ```html
@{foreach m in sitemap()} @{m.name} @{end}
``` __View index.html__: ```html @{sitemap('homepage')}

@{title}

``` __View terms.html__: ```html @{sitemap('terms')}

@{title}

``` __View privacy.html__: ```html @{sitemap('privacy')}

@{title}

``` __View contact.html__: ```html @{sitemap('contact')}

@{title}

``` ### Usage in the code - [framework.sitemap](#api~Framework~framework.sitemap) `+v1.9.1` ```javascript // Finds only the one item and it returns Object console.log(F.sitemap('terms', true)); // Finds all items in the sitemap tree and it returns Array console.log(F.sitemap('terms')); ```

A dependency file `/dependencies` (`+v1.9.0`) is very helpful for installing different dependencies from URL address like models, modules, controllers, configuration files, packages, etc.. The dependency file `/dependencies` is a plain text and has same syntax as __framework config file__.

```html
/controllers

/dependencies

File: `/dependencies` with:

```html
module              : https://modules.totaljs.com/ddos/v1.00/ddos.js
package             : https://modules.totaljs.com/console/v1.01/console.package
package             : https://modules.totaljs.com/webcounter/v1.02/webcounter.package --> { "url": "/online/" }
```

Example:

```html
package            : http://url-address.com --> { "custom-settings": "serialized in JSON format" }

`+2.4.0` supports up-to-date feature and now your dependencies can be up-to-date.

package  (1 day)    : http://url-address.com --> { "custom-settings": "serialized in JSON format" }

pages.body: ## Versioning static files The framework (`+v1.9.0`) has great mechanism for versioning of static files. The versioning is supported via `/versions` file in app root directory. The versioning is very great solution for solving HTTP cache. The versioning file `/versions` is a plain text file and has same syntax as __framework config file__ with except `-->` remapping. So if you have a problem with HTTP cache, this feature saves your time. __Where do I have to store this file?__ ```html /controllers /.js /release.js /versions ``` ## How does it work? File: `/versions` with: ```html /js/default.js : /js/default-101.js /css/default.css : /css/default-105.css /img/logo.png : /img/logo-101.png ``` ### 1. affects all views: ```html @{js('default.js')} --> output will be /js/default-101.js @{img('logo.png')} --> output will be /img/logo-101.png @{css('default.css')} --> output will be /css/default-105.css Output file must exist or must be served via F.merge() or F.map()) --> output will be --> output will be --> output will be ``` ### 2. affects `F.merge()` and `F.map()`: ```javascript F.merge('/js/default.js', 'scriptA.js', 'scriptB.js'); // The framework automatically remaps F.merge() on the background to: // F.merge('/js/default-101.js', 'scriptA.js', 'scriptB.js'); F.map('/js/default.js', 'newfile.js'); // The framework automatically remaps F.map() on the background to: // F.map('/js/default-101.js', 'newfile.js'); ``` --- File: `/versions` with remapping: > Below solution solves problem with renaming of files. You don't need to rename file `/img/logo.png` to `img/logo-101.png`. The framework automatically creates a file mapping. So in the prax: you change old __logo file__ without renaming. ```html /img/logo.png --> /img/logo-101.png ``` The framework automatically creates `F.map()` e.g. `F.map('/img/logo-101.png','/img/logo.png')` and it has same behaviour like versioning without remapping. --- - [Example: versioning of static files](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/static-version)
